intro: Habranthus hesperius var. pallidus, commonly known as the pallid morning glory, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Convolvulaceae family and is characterized by its trumpet-shaped, pale blue to white flowers that open in the morning. The plant has heart-shaped leaves with a hairy texture and produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often growing along rocky outcrops and dry streambeds. Its ornamental value and ecological significance make it a notable species in its native habitat.
